Onardjon was widowed early. However, in spite of the difficulties presented to her by fate, Onardjon has not given up. She independently raised her girls. She has given them an education. She has married them off. And all is thanks to her strong female will and hardworkingness. 

She lives together with her youngest daughter and her son-in-law. As commanded by fate, her son-in-law has replaced her son. He is also very hardworking. He always supports Onardjon and helps her with everything with all his strength. Having consulted with her son-in-law, they have decided to take a loan to increase their number of cattle. In the future, they plan to open a farm to expand their cattle breeding.

loans.use: to buy a cattle

loans.name: Ion

texts.en: Ion is a butcher by profession and a salesman by nature. He welcomes customers to his table with a big smile and proudly displays the various cuts of meat. He buys beef and pork live from farmers in the many villages surrounding his town and slaughters them himself, taking care to get the most efficient cuts from each. His reputation for good quality meat have earned this entrepreneur loyal customers, and to serve them better, Ion wishes to add chicken to his product offerings. He needs a loan to purchase the initial quantities of meat already prepared from a vendor in the city.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Taufau

texts.en: Taufau is married with one son. She used to be a teacher but she taught for only 5 years then resigned because she wasn’t unable to earn a stable salary. Seeking another source of income, Taufau decided to start her own small business. She asked permission from her relatives for a piece of land she can use, and was granted a ½ acre plot to start her taro plantation. Taufau is a Christian lady who believes in the power of prayers. She began her business in 2004 and it is becoming really successful. She supplies taro to village people who make taro chips, and also supplies hotels nearby, and has found herself a market to export her Taro to our neighboring island that is under control by America. She believes her new market of trade will help her generate additional profit. Her main goal is for her business to grow, ensuring the wellbeing of her family and helping to provide an education for her son at a good college.

loans.use: Buy organic fertizers, pesticides, and knives

loans.name: Toga

texts.en: Toga is known for her pancakes, and is requesting a loan so she can expand her baking business. She is now going to be baking Puligi (cakes) that many families enjoy with their morning tea. The cakes will be more profitable, because they sell for a higher price. She will use her loan money to buy a second-hand oven and to extend the back of her house to accommodate her baking business.

loans.use: To purchase flour, baking powder, eggs, butter, timber, nails, cement for kitchen extension

loans.name: Senovia

texts.es:
My name is Senovia, I am a merchant and my main activity is to sell fruits of the season. My stand is located in the center of my colony. I have dedicated many years to this activity, which generates income. I am able to contribute to the family expenses with the profit of my business.

Translated to English by Patricia Yáñez, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Senovia, soy comerciante, mi actividad principal es la venta de frutas de temporada, ubicado en el centro de mi colonia, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad, la que me genera ingresos y con las utilidades puedo colaborar con los gastos de mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase of fruits of the season

loans.name: Adan De La Cruz

texts.en:
My name is Adan de la Cruz and I have a small grocery stand in the city market. I have run this business for several years and generate sufficient income to cover my family's living expenses and to meet my obligations to my suppliers. Thanks to this business I have been able to finance my children's education and allowed them to obtain their high school diplomas.

I feel very fortunate to have my children's help in their free time. I am requesting this loan to purchase more inventory to allow me to offer my customers a greater product selection.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Hola mi nombres es Adan de la Cruz, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuenta con una pequeña pulperia uibcada en el Mercado Municipal de mi ciudad, tengo varios años de dedicarme a esta actividad, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos de mi familia y demas compromisos con los proveedores, gracias ha este negocio he dado a mis hijos educación. logrando asi titulos de educación media para cada uno ( 4). me siento muy contento ya que cuento con la colaboración de mis hijos en su tiempo libre actualemnte necesito surtir mas el negocio y poder ofrecer a mis clientes variedad de productos.

loans.use: To purchase rice, corn, sugar, lard, poultry, oil, dairy products and soap

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Mrs. Charity I. lives in Benin City. A married mother of 4 children, she is 35 years old. She runs a restaurant and wishes to buy more drinks, starch and food items for sale with the loan of $1175. She has been in this business since 2001 and is a leader of her union. 'I am glad to be a member of LAPO' says Mrs. Charity I..

loans.use: To buy more food and drinks

loans.name: Naiba

texts.en: Naiba K. is a 65-year-old married woman who lives in the southern part of Azerbaijan in the Imishli region. Naiba raises and sells cattle. She has fifteen years of experience in animal breeding. Local bazaar traders know Naiba very well and always come to purchase cattle.  Meat is in very high demand all across Azerbaijan and people eat fresh meat at homes and in cafes.  As the result there is much competition in this business. Naiba works very hard to cover family needs. She has four children, two sons and two daughters. She is going to expand her business and purchase one cow. She is going to sell dairy products. It will improve her life conditions and bring her meaningful income.  Naiba has applied for 800 USD with a repayment term of 15 months. The estimated cost for one cow is 700-800 USD.

loans.use: To purchase one dairy  cow

loans.name: Majeedan

texts.en: “I am Majeedan B. and have lived all my life in the small town of Vehari. I am married with four children. My husband and I have been running a bedding business for the past 12 years. We purchase bed sheets from large cities and sell door-to-door in our town and surrounding villages. We purchase each piece for US$ 4 and re-sell it for $9 to $10. We require a loan so that we can purchase bedding in bulk. Last year we took out a loan as well and reinvested the profits into our business. With the profits this year, I am hoping to have a doctor look at my father’s eyes. He's having trouble with his eyesight.”

loans.use: Purchase bedsheets wholesale for re-sale

loans.name: Martha Lucila

texts.es:
Martha Lucila M. is the mother of 4 children who are currently attending high school. For about 14 years, she's been selling food in the city of Chinandega, specifically in the city's municipal market. Her business began when her partner in life lost his job and although he devoted himself to finding a job was unsuccessful. This obviously resulted in a household crisis, and Martha had not alternative and decided, along with her husband, to invest their savings in a general store.

To fulfill her need in acquiring products for her store, Martha has been working with CEPRODEL for 4 years and is very happy with her loans because they have been provided during times when she needed them the most. Currently, she has a record of 19 loans, which of course, have been paid in a timely manner in accordance with the provisions set forth by CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Martha Lucila M. es madre de 4 hijos que actualmente están estudiando la secundaria, el negocio de esta señora es venta de comida desde hace 14 años en la ciudad de Chinandega, específicamente en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa. Su negocio lo inicia al quedar su compañero de vida sin trabajo y al dedicarse a buscar otro empleo no lo encontraba y por tal motivo la crisis se venia apoderando de su hogar. Como no encontraba alternativa, la señora M. decide invertir junto con su esposo sus ahorros para la implementación de la pulpería.

Para suplir su necesidad de adquisición de los productos para la pulpería, doña Martha trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 4 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados pues se los han brindados en el momento que mas los ha necesitado. Actualmente ella tiene un record de 19 créditos que por supuesto han sido pagados en tiempo y forma de acuerdo a lo establecido.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell in her store. (Adquisicion de los productos)

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias Group

texts.en:
Deliana is a 22 year old woman who lives with her husband and three children (ages: 5, 4, 2) in the small community of Cangrejo, which is on the northern coast of the Dominican Republic. This is the first loan she has applied for through Kiva and she is really excited to expand her current business. Over the past couple of years she has been selling different types of homemade food to the people in her community. With this loan she wants to set up a storefront by her home and expand the variety of food she is able to make every day.

When she is not working she loves talking with her friends and catching up with her neighbors.

She wants to thank everyone who is supporting her loan and has taken the time to read about her life and business. On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and on behalf of Deliana, we thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase materials to build a store; expand inventory of food staples, fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ke

texts.en: Mrs. Ke S. and her husband, Phan Von, are pot and statue carvers who live in the Mol Village, Pursat Province. They have two children, both of whom are students. With their stable sculpture business, they earn about $6 per day but this income cannot support their family’s expenses and children’s school fees, so they need to expand the business. They now request a loan of $1,100 to buy wood for stock to make pot and statue sculptures more efficiently. The photo is of S.'s husband.

loans.use: To buy wood for stock to make pot and statue sculptures more efficiently

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
M. Aba is a fishmonger. She is married and has 7 dependents. She buys fresh fish from the fishermen and processes and sells it to her customers. She wants to increase sales to meet the demand of her customers.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.name: Samey

texts.en:
Mr. Samey R. repairs motorcycles for a living in the Khsom Village of Kandal Province. His wife, Mrs. Vanny Mao (pictured on the right), is a fortune-teller in the local village. Mr. Samey R. is the father of four children, one of whom is attending school while the others are too young to work or study.

In recent months, his business has faced mounting problems because he does not have enough money to afford equipment which enable him to make repairs on the motorcycles his clients bring to him for service. Thus, Mr. Samey R. is seeking a loan to buy such equipment.

loans.use: To purchase equipment in order to repair his customers' motorcycles.

loans.name: Aisha Namanda's Group

texts.en:
Aisha is the leader of 5 members. She is 35 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are 6, 10, and 13 years old and all attend school. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Aisha has been selling shoes for 3 years in the village of Kazo. The market for her business is fair, and her main challenge is earning enough money when she doesn’t have enough customers.

Aisha plans on using this loan to pay her children’s school fees and invest in more shoes to sell. She has successfully paid back 4 loans and in doing so has been able to feed her family and educate her children. In addition, she hopes to one day fulfill her dream of buying a plot of land where she could eventually build a house.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
Mrs. Ouch K., 31, is a farmer as well as grocery seller in Tasas Village, Pursat Province. She earns around $1.50 per day. Her husband, Mr. Sang Soeurm, works growing rice with his wife. K. buys grocery inventory from the town market and transports everything by bicycle to sell around her village. In order to grow her business, she wants to make more profit and so she is asking for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a secondhand motorcycle to use as transportation for her business. The loan will allow her to increase their income through transporting more groceries to sell and saving time.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motorcycle to use as transportation for her business

loans.name: Mwajuma's Kujikwaa Si Kuanguka Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 25 years old. She is divorced and she has 2 children aged 4 and 8 years old. She has been selling charcoal and snacks since 2005. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 3 PM at her business.

Mwajuma is requesting a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Fatma and Asha, who have businesses dealing with charcoal and firewood sales, and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina M., 28 years old, lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu. She lives in a single family household with 4 family members: her husband, 30-year-old Shyam M., and two sons who are six years and two years old.

She and her husband work together in their furniture shop. She needs a loan to purchase some materials for their shop like wood, a saw and other items. She seeks Rs 10000/-for her shop in order to earn more and maintain the family .

loans.use: To buy timber and a saw

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en: Hanan is the mother of one child and lives in Beirut. She is 24 years old and owns a small shop that specializes in selling lingerie. Hanan has requested a loan of $500 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase more products for her shop. She believes that it is very important to have variety of styles and colors for her clients to choose from, and is confident that this loan will allow her to expand her clientele and increase her profits.

loans.use: To diversify her clothing stock.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy Es socia del Banco Comunal Claveles.
Nancy es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 2 hijos, Nancy vende frutas variadas en un puesto del mercado 12 de abril, su puesto esta ubicado cerca de una de las puertas de acceso al mercado, las frutas los adquiere en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, los días sábados y domingos cuenta con la ayuda de sus hijos.
Nancy necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de papaya y piña.
Los sueños de Nancy son mejorar su casa, tener una tienda de abarrotes y sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Nancy is a member of the Banco Comunal Claveles. Nancy is 34 years old and has two children. She sells a variety of fruits at a stand in the 12th of April market. Her stand is located near one of the entrances to the market. She acquires the fruits at the supply market of the city of Ayacucho. On saturdays and sundays her children help her. Nancy asks for a loan to invest in the purchase of papaya and pineapple. Her dreams are to improve her home, to have a grocery stand, and to see her children grow up to be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of papaya and pineapple

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es: Vilma tiene 33 años, es conviviente, tiene 3 hijos pequeños que por el momento  están viviendo en la casa de sus suegros. Cuando estaba soltera en la zona rural de la ciudad de Tarma trabajando en la chacra, desde que hizo familia se dedicó primero a vender papas en el mercado, pero esto le era muy trabajoso y no muy rentable, entonces cambió de rubro, ahora compra y vende ropa interior y calcetines, en el mercado donde vende encuentra mucha competencia, pero igual continúa y se esfuerza para crecer. Lo bueno es que cuando junta capital puede comprar grandes cantidades y eso le es más rentable y sobre todo a ella le gusta vender y estar en contacto con la gente. Es su 5to préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma, no ha tenido dificultades en sus pagos hasta el momento. Con el dinero solicitado va invertir en la compra de prendas en mayor cantidad, para fin de año piensa comprar ropa amarilla, debido a la tradición de usar una prenda de ese color para recibir el nuevo año.
texts.en:
Vilma is 33 years old. She lives with her partner and has three small children who, at the moment, are living at her mother- and father-in-law's house. When she was single, she worked on a ranch in the rural area of the city of Tarma. Since beginning a family, she first dedicated herself to selling potatoes in the market. However, this was very hard work and not very profitable so she changed her line of business. Now she buys and sells underwear and socks. In the market where she sells, there is a lot of competition but she continues anyways and she works hard to grow. What's good is when she has capital to be able to buy great quantities and this is more profitable. Above all, she enjoys sales and being in contact with people. This is her fifth loan with Microfinanzas Prisma. She has not had any difficulties with her payments preivously. With the money that she is requesting, she is going to invest in the purchase of garments in a greater quantity. For the end of the year, she's thinking of buying yellow clothing, due to the tradition of using a garment of this color to receive the new year.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing for the New Year celebration.

loans.name: Rina

texts.es: Rina tiene 30 años, vive junto a su conviviente y su hijo que tiene 3 añitos de edad. Ella se dedica a la venta de cerveza en su casa desde hace 2 años, le gusta mucho su trabajo porque conoce a mucha gente con quien mantiene amenas conversaciones. Durante todo este tiempo su negocio le está permitiendo fortalecer su nivel económico y el de su familia, y como trabaja con una marca muy reconocida, el consumo es asegurado. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, por lo que se ha comprometido en ser responsable con su banco comunal y con sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado mandará a construir un pequeño local al costado de su casa para su negocio, también comprará más cajas de cerveza.
texts.en:
Rina is 30-years old and lives with her companion and her son who is 3-years old. For the last two-years, she has dedicated herself to selling beer from her home. She enjoys this line of work because she gets to meet many people with whom she can converse with.

During this time, her business has grown and so too has her family. They work with a very recognizable brand that customers trust. This is the first time she is requesting a loan from MFP, and she understands her responsibility to the community bank and her debt to pay. With this loan, she will have a small partition built from the house for her business. Rina will also purchase more crates of beer.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To construct a small place for her business

loans.name: Grupo El Flamingo Group

texts.es:
Este es el grupo Flamingo es originario de el municipio de Catarina, está compuesto por tres integrantes: Mercedes Amanda A., Elia María S. G., Rosa del Carmen H. A., mujeres amigas y vecinas, decidieron integrar el grupo para obtener el financiamiento y salir adelante.
Doña Rosa del Carmen, mujer de 42 años de edad, madre de 4 hijos adolescentes de los cuales todos estudian en la escuela del municipio, su actividad es elaborar y vender canastos, en el negocio participan ella, sus hijos y su esposo, la señora vende los canastos en el mercado Oriental de Managua, pero el taller está en su casa de habitación. Esta actividad la aprendió de sus padres que tenían este mismo negocio. El crédito lo necesita para comprar bambú en varas, este lo compra en fincas de Nandaime, en las faldas de el cerro Bombacho, para hacer este viaje tiene que contratar vehículo para traerlos a su casa, en ocasiones tiene que pagar el lote de cañas por adelantado.
texts.en:
The group Flamingo are natives of the Catarina municipality and has 3 members: Mercedes Amanda A., Elia María S. G., Rosa del Carmen H. A.. These women are friends and neighbors who decided to form a group to obtain financing and move forward. Mrs. Rosa del Carmen is 42 years old and is the mother of 4 adolescent children, all of whom study in the municipal school. She makes and sells baskets and her children and husband participate in the business. She sells the baskets in the Oriental de Managua market, but her workshop is a room in her house. She learned this activity from her parents who had the same business. The loan is need to buy bamboo canes which she buys from Nandaime farms in the foothills of Bombacho and for this trip she has hire a vehicle to bring them home and occasionally she has to pay for a lot of canes in advance.

Translated from Spanish by Jeanette Chase, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Benkadi sont  en majorité mariées. Elles ont  une moyenne d’âge de 23 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des familles conjugales nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans la ville de Dioïla région de Koulikoro république du Mali. Elles se sont connues  par des relations de commerces.
 Dans le souci d’améliorer leurs activités elles ont adhéré à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire. Aucun prêt précèdent n’a fait l’objet de mauvais remboursement. 
Avec ce dixième prêt elles comptent acheter, 600 kg d’aubergines, 280 kg d’oranges, 120 kg de papayes et une grande quantité de légumes vertes. Elles achètent ces produits dans les jardins potagers de Dioïla pour les revendre dans la même ville au grand marché en détail au comptant et à crédit. Leur clientèle est composée de restauratrices, de ménagères et les amateurs de fruits et légumes.
 Elles comptent obtenir avec ce prêt un  bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux frais scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
Most of the women in the Benkadi group are married. They average 23 years of age and 3 children. They live in nuclear traditional families, with their children and husbands, in the city of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region in the Republic of Mali. They got acquainted through business bonds. Anxious to improve their businesses, they joined Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their tenth solidarity loan (group loan). None of the previous loans was affected by bad reimbursement.

With this loan, they intend to buy 600 kg of eggplants, 280 kg of oranges, 120 kg of papayas, and a large amount of green vegetables. They purchase these products in vegetable gardens in Dioïla, to retail them at the grand market of that same city, for cash and on credit. Their clientele mostly comprises women working in the food serving business, housewives, and people fond of fruits and vegetables. They foresee turning a profit of XOF 35'000 (ca US$ 70), to be used to provide for their children's school expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and retail fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Alba Alejandrina

texts.es:
La Sra, Alba Z. tiene una pulperia desde hace varios años, la cual opera bajo el nombre de Pulperia ELSA, su negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitacion, esto le permite no descuidar su hogar ni sus hijos ya que ella es madre de 4. su esposo se dedica a la compra y venta de lacteos en diferentes comunidades y caserios, tambien el ayuda cuando hay produccion de cafe y este es un dinero extra que le entra ya que no todo el año hay produccion de cafe.
Doña Alba nos conto muy alegre que su negocio ha sido una gran bendicion ya que con los ingresos que le ha dado ella a logrado remodelar su casa, ella hace poco hizo una remodelaciona a su casa en todo el techo y esto la dejo un poco descapitalizada y por tal razon quiere un credito para poder salir adelante.
texts.en:
Alba Z. has owned a small grocery store for many years, which she operates under the name Pulperia ELSA. Her business is located in the house in which she lives, and this allows her to care for her home and children given that she is a mother of four. Her husband buys and sells dairy products in different communities and villages; he also helps when there is coffee production, and this is extra money that comes in given that coffee is not produced year round. Alba told us happily that her business has been a great blessing given that with the income that it has given her she was able to remodel her house; not long ago she remodeled her entire roof which left her lacking some capital and for this reason she is requesting a loan to be able to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase lard, oil, margarine, beans, rice, coffee, bread, sugar, soap, soft drinks, juices, churros, eggs, and spices.

loans.name: Mirikrom

texts.ru: Курбоналиев Мирикром житель района Варзоб. Возраст 20 лет, не женат .Живет в семье с родителями. Кроме них с ними живут его ьрат с семьей.  Имеет средне-техническое образование. Работает слесарем  на СТО. Зарабатывает около 200 $  в месяц. Работает много , так как планирует жениться , а на это нужны деньги. Обратился за кредитом для того , чтобы на него купить оборудование, необходимое в работе. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mirikrom K. lives in the Varzob area. He is 20 years old and is not married. He lives with his parents. In addition, his brother and his family live with them. Mirikrom has a secondary-technical education. He works as a mechanic at an auto shop. Mirikrom earns around $200 per month. He works a lot, because he plans to get married and this requires money. He turned to us for a loan in order to purchase equipment which he needs for work. He plans to pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase equipment

loans.name: Hilaria

texts.es: Hilaria tiene 51 años, vive con uno de sus tres hijos, quien es soltero, mientras que los demás ya son independientes y de familia. Desde hace 2 años se dedica a la venta de abarrotes (arroz, azúcar, frijoles, etc.) y productos de primera necesidad, en un espacio al frente de su casa, y cuenta con el apoyo de su hijo cada vez que lo necesita. Lo que le gusta de esta actividad es estar en contacto con sus clientes, con quienes comparte muchos diálogos y les da un muy buen trato para que siempre regresen a comprarle. Este negocio le es muy rentable, ya que se encuentra ubicada en una muy buena zona, por donde transitan muchas personas, además es la única que cuenta con este tipo de negocio, y le va muy bien. Con MFP ya tiene 5 préstamos, nos cuenta que últimamente están habiendo problemas en su banco comunal porque hay personas que no son responsables en sus pagos, por lo que espera que pronto se pueda solucionar esta dificultad para continuar con el normal desarrollo de su grupo. Todo el dinero que viene solicitando lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería para su negocio.
texts.en:
Hilaria is 51 years-old and lives with one of her three children who is single (the rest have families and are independent). For the last 2 years (with the help of her son) , she has sold groceries (rice, sugar, beans, etc.) as well as hygiene items out of a space in the front of her house. She enjoys the personal contact with her clients, with whom she shares a great rapport. Because she treats them well, they continually return to purchase products from her. Her business is successful due to its ideal, high-transit location; additionally, she is the only person in her neighborhood who runs this type of business. She has received 5 loans from MFP. She hopes that her fellow borrowers will be responsible with their re-payments (there have been recent problems regarding this issue) so that her group will be able to continue its development. She will use the money from this loan to purchase more merchandise for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jim Muir, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Elizabeth tiene 22 años, vive en el distrito de Florencia de Mora, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió hasta el 4to de Educación Secundaria, tiene 4 hijos los cuales dependen económicamente de ella.
Elizabeth se dedica a la venta de tamales, inició su negocio vendiendo tamales en la esquina de su casa, ahora tiene su negocio frente al hospital EsSalud ubicado en su distrito, adicionando la preparación de tamales que realiza para eventos (trabaja con pedidos). 
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal Unidas para un Futuro Mejor II, lo invirtió en la compra de una canasta y maíz.
Con el crédito de 1000 soles que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de insumos (panca y maíz) para la preparación de tamales y en herramientas para la carpintería que administra en asociación con su esposo.
Elizabeth tiene como sueño brindarle la facilidad y mejores estudios para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is 22 years old and lives in the Florencia de Mora, province of Trujillo, located in La Libertad, Perú.  She studied until the 4th year of Secondary School, and has 4 children who depend on her economically. Elizabeth dedicates herself to the sale of tamales, having started by selling these on the street corner near her house. She now has her business in front of the hospital located in her district. She also makes special order tamales for events. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from her cooperative bank Unidas para un Futuro Mejor II (“United for a Better Future II”), she invested in purchasing baskets and corn. With the loan of 1000 soles, to be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in purchasing supplies (chili peppers and corn) to make tamales. She will also buy tools for the carpentry activities she carries out together with her husband. Elizabeth’s dream is to provide for her children, including giving them good educations.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies (chili peppers and corn) to make tamales.

loans.name: Hermilia

texts.es:
Hermilia es socia del Bancomunal Mujeres del Dos Mil.
Hermilia  es casada tiene 49 años, cuatro hijos  el menor tiene 15 años y está estudiando en la escuela estatal 
Hermilia  vive frente a un colegio y vendía golosinas pero las ganancias eran pocas, por consejo de una amiga decidió vender  tamales  y desde entonces se dedica  a la venta de tamales hace ocho años y dos veces a la semana trabaja en un taller de costura.
Hermilia necesita un préstamo de  1200 soles para la preparación de tamales,   y descartables al por mayor. 
Desde que Hermilia está en Finca aprendió a invertir antes no hacía nada con el dinero, se lo gastaba 
 El sueño de Hermilia es hacer una librería en su casa.
texts.en:
Hermilia is a member of the Communal Bank Women of the Two Thousand. Hermilia is married, 49 years old, and has four children, the youngest of which is 15 and is studying at the state school. Hermilia lives in front of a school where she sold sweets but earned little, because of this she took the advice of a friend and decided to sell tamales. For the past eight years she has dedicated herself to the sale of tamales, and twice a week she works in a sewing shop. Hermilia needs a loan of 1,200 PEN for the preparation of tamales and to purchase wholesale disposable serving ware. Since Hermilia has been with Finca she has learned to invest, she used to do nothing with her money or would spend it, and since has changed. Hermilia dreams of having a bookstore in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hermilia needs a loan of 1,200 PEN for the preparation of tamales and to purchase wholesale disposable serving ware.

loans.name: Janet's Group

texts.en:
N. Janet is the chairperson of Alinyikira group in Mutundwe. She is a strong business lady with a retail shop for 3 years and a poultry farm for a long time, both businesses she transacts at her home. In the shop, she sells general merchandise and eggs from her chickens while she also keeps broilers and layers interchangeably. She is seeking her 6th year while taking loans with the group, and she hopes to stock her shop with more goods plus buy more feed for her chickens.

Janet is a lucky mother. She has 7 children of whom 5 are graduates at the best university of Makerere while 2 are soon completing their studies at the same university. On top of this, she pays school fees and caters for 4 orphaned nephews in secondary and primary school.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop and buying feed for her poultry farm

loans.name: Pamela Atieno

texts.en:
Pamela has a business selling small fish from Lake Victoria. She buys the omena, as the fish are called, from her aunt and sells them in the market in Kitale, Kenya, on Tuesdays and Thursdays. Having only been in business for a year, Pamela is already making a good profit. From each 10,000 shilling barrel of fish that she buys, she can earn between 4,000 and 5,000 shillings in profit. Her biggest expenses are her transportation costs going to and from Kitale by bus from Kisumu. With the proceeds from her business, Pamela has already built a home and is renting out a part of it for additional income. Her dream for her business is to someday buy a pick-up truck so that she can carry her goods to the market by herself, but for now she is happy to take out a loan to increase her volume of fish to sell.

In addition to running her business, she volunteers as a community health worker and teaches children in a nursery. She also looks after her late aunt’s 14-year-old child, carrying the financial burden of her school fees and transportation.

K-MET, the NGO providing this loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, please use the following link: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is twenty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, a boy and two girls who are all currently in primary school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town in the western region of Ghana. Paulina is a petty trader. She sells textiles – underwear for both men and women. She hawks her wares in her community.

Paulina buys the textiles from Kumasi. She also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy bales of textiles in bulk to expand her business. She desires to give her children quality education and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy underwear for resale

loans.name: Juana Maria

texts.es: La joven Juana Maria A. B., tiene la edad de 28 años habita en el sector de los cocos ubicado en la Concepción, junto a su esposo, el trabaja como transportista para ayudarle con los gastos de la casa, ella se desempeña como niñera en la embajada Americana desde hace tres años, ellos tiene una hija de cuatros años, los planes hacia la familia es terminar de construir su casa, doña Juana solicita la cantidad de C$ 5,000.00 ya que los va a  invertir en materiales de construcción para comenzar a construir su vivienda. Da las gracias a la institución por los beneficios para poder mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Juana Maria A. B. is 28. She lives in the area of the coconuts located in Concepción. She lives with her husband. He works as a driver to help her with the household expenses. She has worked as a nanny for three years in the American embassy. They have a four year old daughter. The family plan is to finish building their house. Juana is asking for 5,000 NIO to buy construction materials to start building her house. She is grateful to the institution for the benefit of being able to improve her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to make improvements on her house

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria es socia del Banco Comunal Amaquella que significa No seas Flojo en quechua.
Victoria es casada, tiene 59 años y 5 hijos, Victoria tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, verduras, frutas, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda D. sus hijos.
Victoria necesita un préstamo D. 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. leche, aceite y azúcar.
Los sueños D. Victoria son mejorar sus negocios y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the Communal Bank Amaquella (which means “Don’t Be Lazy" in Quecha). She is 59 years old, married, and has 5 children.

Victoria operates a store out her home where she sells groceries, vegetables, and fruit. She works every day with the assistance of her children.

Victoria needs a loan of 1050 soles in order to buy milk, oil and sugar. She dreams of improving her business and that her children become professionals.

Click HERE to view Victoria's previous loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase milk, oil & sugar

loans.name: Precious

texts.en: Precious is 32 years old and married with three children. She sells foodstuffs like gari (couscous-like grain made from grated cassava) and other food items. She has been in the business for the past six years. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more bags of gari to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more gari  to sell

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Filomena is a member of the We are Leaders village bank. She is 42 years old, married, and has two children aged 13 and 19. Her eldest child is studying to be a physical therapist and her youngest is in public school.

Filomena is from Puno. She studied sewing briefly in Lima, but was unable to finish her studies as she cannot speak Spanish very well. Filomena speaks Aymara, but no one in Lima speaks this dialect. In addition, she has trouble speaking and her friends criticize the way she speaks. Filomena worked in various areas until her aunt advised her to start raising pigs. Raising pigs is profitable, does not take all day, and buyers are always available.

Filomena is requesting a loan of 2000 PEN to buy feed for the pigs and sacks of sweet potatoes. Her dream is to buy a car and rent it out to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and sacks of sweet potatoes

loans.name: Vicente Angel

texts.es:
El señor Vicente Ángel C. vive con su esposa la señora Rafaela son una familia muy unida y responsable, pero sobretodo emprendedora, iniciaron su propio negocio  desde hace 6 años de nombre “Carpintería C.”.
El tiene por el momento un pedido grande de muebles y esta requiriendo este crédito para la compra de materia prima.
texts.en:
Mr. Vicente Ángel C. lives with his wife Rafaela. They are a very close and responsible family. Above all they are very enterprising. They started their own business, “Carpintería C.” (C. Carpenter Shop) six years ago. He has received a large order from a customer for furniture and he needs this loan to buy raw materials.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raw materials for furniture making

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Mrs. Nilda C. is from the village of Gango. She is 46 years-old and married with three adult children. Nilda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store selling home products. She has been engaged in her business for twenty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, she joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC.

Nilda is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products for her retail store. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean is a married woman. She is 37 years old and has three kids. Her eldest child is only twelve. She does rice farming for a living. According to Jean, her rice crops are growing well but still need additional inputs. To supply her needs, she applied for a loan of 12,000 PHP from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Jean will use this loan to purchase necessary farming supplies and she is hopeful that this loan will truly help her achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farming Supplies

loans.name: Rath Theany

texts.en:
Rath Theany U. sells fish and chickens and breeds pigs.  She and her husband live in Kampong Svay village in Kandal province.  Her business is going well and she wants to expand by purchasing more fish and chickens to resell to earn more income. 

Her husband, Prech Mao, is a cooker who is hired by villagers during weddings, ceremonies, birthday parties, and so on.  Rath is 24 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.  Her husband is pictures to her right in the photo.

loans.use: Buy more fishes and chickens to resell to earn more income.

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Jiguisseme sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans,  4 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kaboila village, 3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur vingtième  prêt de groupe. Les précédents se sont tous bien dénoués. 
Elles font entre autre  la vente de tissus, du sounbala, de layettes etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,1 vingtaine de complets tissus  pour femme, 5 sacs de 100kg de graines de néré et des dizaines de laines de couleurs différentes. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marché  de Kaboila village  et souvent à Sikasso, de façon ambulante ou fixe et à domicile, au comptant, en détail et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 37.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Jiguisseme group are essentially married women who have an average age of 38 years and an average of 4 children; most of them live in polygamous families in the village of Kaboila in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They work with the microfinance company, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to be able to satisfy the demand of their customers and are on their 20th group loan. The previous loans have all been repaid without problem. They sell among other things fabrics, sounbala (a condiment), baby clothes etc..With their new loan they are planning to buy 20 women's suits, five 100g bags of néré seeds and tens of wools in all different colours. They buy their stock on the market at Sikasso and in neighboring villages. They sell their products at the market in Kaboila village and often in Sikasso, either moving around or at a fixed place and in peoples' homes. They sell retail for cash and often on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. They are expecting to make a monthly profit of 37,500 FCFA each, of which part will be used for savings and family needs, and part to invest in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es:
Descripción: El señor Santiago tiene una despensa en su casa y una librería en el mercado de abasto, trabaja conjuntamente con su esposa, ambos se ayudan en las dos actividades, ellos quieren el crédito para seguir invirtiendo en su negocio, el cual necesita de una inyección constante de capital para seguir creciendo y así satisfacer las demandas de sus clientes. 
Don Santiago tiene casa propia y quiere mejorarlas por lo que siempre hace un esfuerzo por mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Santiago runs a convenience store from his house and he has a supply stand in the large market. He works together with his wife and they both contribute to each business. They request a loan to keep investing in their business, which is constant need of capital funds to maintain its growth and to meet the clients' demands.

Santiago has his own home and he would like to improve his business, so that his revenues will increase.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase paper, pens and other items.

loans.name: Maria Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora María Yolanda, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Sarita Colonia”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Separada, tiene 40 años y es madre de 02 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

María Yolanda, como le dicen de cariño, se dedica a la venta de Comidas y lleva varios años dedicándose a este tipo de actividad, se encuentra ubicada cerca del paradero “Huallaga Central”- Juanjui, y cuenta con un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, donde atiende a sus clientes y pensionistas. Nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas, por la sazón rica que le da a sus preparados, es conocida y tiene muy buena acogida.

En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con su trabajo que realiza día a día. Es ella quien personalmente atiende a sus clientes con el carisma que le caracteriza.

Con este préstamo de S/ 800.00, comprará insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como arroz en kilos, aceites en litros, pollos en javas, verduras y también  algunos utensilios, para dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante aun, tiene muchos sueños y metas en su vida, como implementar su propia tienda de abarrotes, muy bien  acondicionado y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio.
texts.en:
. María Yolanda, 40, is a member of the "Sarita Colonia" communal bank, which is in Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, San Martín province. She is separated and the mother of two dependent children. María Yolanda sells prepared meals; she has done this for several years now. She is located near the "Huallaga Central" - Juanjui bus stop and she has a well-set-up location from which to care for her customers and guests. She tells us that her daily sales are good because she prepares tasty dishes; she is well-known and well-received. Currently, she continues in the same line of work and she is very happy with the daily work she does. It is she, herself, who tends to her customers with her characteristic good humor. With this 800 sol loan she will buy ingredients for her dishes like: kilos of rice, liters of cooking oil, crates of chickens, vegetables and some utensils to provide better customer service. She feels full of life and wants to continue forging ahead; she has many dreams and goals still to reach such as setting up her own, very well-stocked, grocery store. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her start her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her meals preparation.

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi is a 39-year-old single man living with his parents and three siblings. He has owned a gadget, CD and DVD shop since 1995 after seeing a need for such services in the region.

Fadi is a very responsible and punctual client. He chose to repay his first loan early and took a new loan of $1,200. With the new loan, he will invest in buying inventory for his shop in order to expand his business and hence his income.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Jose Leonel

texts.es:
Perfil del Cliente 	El Sr. José Leonel Solís tiene una taller de soldadura en el municipio del el Viejo, el va a usar este crédito en la compra de 2 pistolas de soldar que necesita, una caja de herramientas, y varillas para soldar ya que en la actualidad han salido varios tipos de llaves que le sirven para hacer mas fácil su trabajo.

El Sr. Solís ya tiene varios años con este taller, el cual a través de las ganancias que ha obtenido ahora tiene una panadería en su casa la cual  administra su esposa, además de tener dos camionetas y un microbús que son su medio de transporte para salir a vender el pan. 

Este es el cuarto crédito que ha tenido con CEPRODEL,  el cual nos manifiesta que le han sido de gran ayuda para mejorar su trabajo y su vida personal, ya que gracias a ellos su negocio ha crecido y le ha dejado mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
José Leonel Solís has a soldering shop in the Viejo municipality. He will use this loan to buy two soldering irons that he needs, a toolbox, and soldering rods. There are now various types of wrenches that make his work easier. Mr. Solís has had this shop for several years. With the income he has obtained he now has a bakery, which he wife runs, in his house. He also has two vans and a minibus, which he uses when he leaves to sell the bread. This is his fourth loan with Ceprodel. He says that they have been a great help in improving his work and his personal life. Thanks to the loans his business has grown and given him greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two soldering irons, a tool box with all types of wrenches and sockets, and soldering rods, etc.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is from the village of Labo, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old, is married, and has one school-aged and three adult children.

Jocelyn owns and operates a business planting and harvesting corn for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Despite Angelita B. not being able to graduate her two eldest children from college, she still works hard to be able to send the rest of her seven children to a higher level of education. If she can’t graduate all of them from college, at least she can support them so they become good citizens of the country. Although she sometimes feels sad seeing her family’s poor situation and her eldest child with her husband working hard, farming rice for other people for a small amount of money, she can still pretend that she is happy, especially in front of her children. Her children are aged from 8 to 22. 

Angelita has become hopeful since she became a member of ASHI. Through ASHI products and services, especially loans which can be accessed by the members, she hopes to change her family’s standard of living. Now she is excited about the loan she is requesting through Kiva (ASHI partner) because she can start her own small businesses which are hog/pig fattening and rice selling. She hopes that one day her businesses will grow and she will be able to realize her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening and rice for selling.

loans.name: Rufa

texts.en:
Rufa S. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Rufa is married and has 2 school-aged children. Rufa owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Rufa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month, which is about $66 US, for these activities.

In 2010, Rufa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rufa has successfully repaid her first loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rufa is requesting a second loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia G., 57 years old, works hard at being a good wife to her husband. Aside from taking on the daily chores at home, she is also helping her husband in their livelihood, which is rice farming. Currently, they have good farming operations and she wishes to improve to be able to solve her financial problems. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm inputs like seeds.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame  Aminata  Touré  est âgée de 44 ans,  veuve  et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit  dans le domicile de son feu mari avec ses enfants au quartier Bougoufiè de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Aminata a abandonné l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se marier par volonté parentale. Elle commença le commerce suite au décès  de son mari. Elle débuta par la vente de gâteau, ce commerce lui a permis de comprendre les règles du commerce et de savoir faire le marketing de ses produits. Après ce fut le commerce de l’ail et d’échalotes, qu’elle mène depuis maintenant 17 ans au marché château. Elle est très connue dans ce créneau et jouit d’une grande notoriété. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de réaliser beaucoup de bénéfice,  elle a fait recours à  Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 36 mois après 2 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous bien remboursés. 
Elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 1 tonne  d’échalotes. Elle s’approvisionne  au Burkina Faso et vend au comptant, en gros et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui servira de se prendre en charge (achat de nourriture, habillement des enfants et paiement des frais de scolarité).
Son ambition est de transformer sa maison du banco en dure.
texts.en:
Aminata Toure, aged 44, is widow and mother of three children. She lives in the house of her late husband with her children in the neighborhood Bougoufié Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Aminata dropped out of school in the 9th grade (Basic Malian educational system) to get married by parental will. She started her business after the death of her husband. She began by selling cakes; this business has given her the chance to gain business and marketing expertise. Later she started selling garlic and shallots and she has been now for 17 years in this business. She is well known in the area and enjoys a good reputation. In order to increase her capital and her revenue, 36 months ago she has joined Soro Yiriwaso and she received 2 group loans and 2 individual loans, all fully repaid. She is now receving her third individual loan, that she intends to use to buy a ton of shallots. She buys and sells in Burkina Faso in cash, wholesale and credit to a clientele of men and women. With this loan she plans to earn a monthly income of 120,000 CFA francs, that she will use for the family needs (buy food, clothing for children and payment of tuition fees). Her ambition is to transform her house from adobe to something hard.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Cheam

texts.en: Cheam M., 56, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She and her husband are employed to operate tractors to plow fields for an income of about $5 each per day.  M. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase tractor parts to change out when they are broken. She would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. M. appears in the photograph showing her house under construction.

loans.use: buy tractor parts to replace when they are broken

loans.name: Natalia Fernando

texts.pt:
Natalia B. nasceu na Província de Sofala centro de Moçambique é casada mãe de 2 filhos, de 17, 8 anos, todos eles vão a escola. Vive na casa própria sustenta sua sogra e sobrinha que vivem com ela.

Saiu de Sofala com seus pais para Maputo no tempo da guerra, inicia com os estudos e faz a 9ª. Anos depois teve uma proposta para trabalhar na escola como auxiliar administrativa onde se encontra ate então, aufere mensalmente um valor de 2.188.00mt. com empréstimo adquirido no BIM no valor de 20.000,mt inicia a construção da sua casa, mas devido ao elevado preço do material ela não consegue concluir sua obra e aproxima se a Hluvuku solicitando um empréstimo para o mesma finalidade.

Este é o quarto empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, portas e cimento) para dar continuidade da sua obra. Os três empréstimos anteriores de 3.500.00mt, 5.000.00mt e de 9.00.00mt foram para a mesma finalidade. 

  Esta feliz porque dentro em breve vai se mudar para a sua própria casa e confiante que ira reembolsar cem nenhum problema para aceder a mais empréstimos.
texts.en:
Natalia B. was born in the Sofala province in the center of Mozambique. She is married and is the mother of two children, who are 17 and 8 years old. Both of them attend school. She lives in her own home and also supports her mother-in-law and niece, who live with her.

She left Sofala with her parents for Maputo during the war. She studied through 9th grade. Years later, she was offered a job in the school as an administrative assistant, where she continues to work today. She earns 2,188MT each month.

With the loan she got from BIM for 20,000MT, she began construction on her home. However, due to the elevated price of materials, she was not able to finish the construction, and she approached Hluvuku to seek additional loans for the same purpose. This is her fourth loan, and is for the amount of 10,000MT. She plans to use this loan to purchase construction materials (sheet metal, cement, etc.) to continue work on her home. The three previous loans were for 3,500MT, 5,000MT and 9,000MT and were used for the same purpose.

She is happy because soon she will be able to move into her own home and she is confident that she will be able to repay the loan without any problems.

Translated from Portuguese by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras Group

texts.es:
El comité “Las Triunfadoras” se encuentra dentro del 6to. Ciclo del Programa de Comités de Mujeres en la ciudad de Roque Alonso. 
Cada una de las integrantes trabajan en actividades diferentes, pero además se reúnen constantemente para realizar algunas actividades en grupo.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Nancy  quien se dedica a la reposteria elaborando tortas para fiesta infantiles, quince años, bodas y otros.
Ella estudio un buen tiempo para adquirir la profesión de repostera.
Ella trabaja de acuerdo a los pedidos que recibe de sus clientes, los fines de semana con mucho mas auge que los otros días, puede llegar a tener 3 a 4 pedidos de tortas los fines de semana. 
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de una batidora ya que le será muy util en su trabajo, ademas desea comprar algunos ingredientes para reposteria como harinas especiales, azucar, colorantes y otros.
texts.en:
The “Las Triunfadoras” ("The Winners") Group is in its sixth cycle of the Women's Group Program in the city of Roque Alonso. Each of the members works in a different activity, but they get together regularly to complete various activities as a group. One of the group's members is Ms. Nancy, who works as a confectioner. She makes cakes for children's parties, quinceañeras, weddings, and other events. Nancy studied for a good amount of time in order to become a pastry baker. She works according to the orders she receives from her customers, with the weekends much busier than other days. She can receive 3 or 4 cake orders for a weekend. She is requesting this loan to purchase an electric mixer, as it would be very useful in her work. She would also like to buy certain ingredients for her cakes, such as special flours, sugar, food coloring, and other ingredients.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an electric mixer, sugar, flour, food coloring, and other ingredients for baking cakes

loans.name: Chuluuntsetseg

texts.en:
Chuluuntsetseg J. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, on their own land. Her husband is a constructor. In the summertime, he has many orders to build at a small resort camp. Her son, Narmandakh, is 21 years old and works in the Bimex company. Her oldest daughter, Oyunnaran, is 18 years old and this year, she will attend university. Her younger two children, aged 16 and 13, attend secondary school. 

Chuluuntsetseg currently operates a construction-material trade business out of a rented stall at the largest market in Ulaanbaatar. Since Chuluuntsetseg started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and paying her daughter's education fees. She is an open and very hardworking person. She is requesting a loan to purchase current assets. This is her fifth loan with Credit Mongol.

loans.use: To purchase current assets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wood to use as a fuel for making hot water

loans.name: Eugenio Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Eugenio Ramón O. S. es Joyero, posee un tramo en el sector del bisne,  realiza trabajos como anillos, chapas, cadenas de oro y de platas, según cual prefiera el cliente, es casado, tiene 4 hijos pero solo uno depende de él, los demás son independientes y uno de ellos se dedica también a la joyería.

El Señor Eugenio Ramón O. S., tiene 50 años de dedicarse al trabajo de joyería, lleva ya 42 créditos con CEPRODEL, y siempre ha pagado muy puntual sus créditos.
texts.en:
Eugenio Ramón O. S. is a jewler who has a shop in the Bisne sector. He works with rings, metal, gold and silver chains, whichever the customer prefers. He is married and has four children, but only one who is still dependent on him. The others are on their own now. One of his other sons is also a jeweler. Eugenio has been doing this for 50 years. He has had 42 previous loans through CEPRODEL and has always made his payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies; gold and silver

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en: Shirley A. is 47 years old, married and has 4 children (one is adult-aged and three are school-aged). She is from the village of Southern Pob, Mapang. To make a living, she owns and operates a business in the retail sector running a general store. From this activity, she is able to earn a monthly income of 2,800 PHP. She has been engaged in her business for ten years. In 2009, Shirley joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and be able to engage in business activities. Shirley has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Shirley from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Veronica's Group

texts.en:
Veronica B. is 26 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Viga, a part of Angadanan municipality in the province of Isabela on the Luzon islands. Veronica is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Veronica runs a general store from which she sells both food and daily use products to the local community. Veronica has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Veronica joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first from ASKI, of 7000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hayk

texts.en: Hayk S., his wife and three children live with Hayk’s mother in Arteni village, Armenia. The family's main income comes from land cultivation and cattle breeding. Hayk is very good in taking care of his own and neighbours' fruit orchids. During the harvest, Hayk collects fruits from his and neighbours’ orchids and sells in the nearby cities. To increase the life of fruits and thus extend the business season, Hayk is planning to build a cooler for fruits.

loans.use: Building a cooler for fruit.

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambath T. (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Sopha Sun, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2000, and have one daughter who is in school. 

Mrs. Sambath T. has been a silk weaver for more than 9 years. Her husband is a construction worker. She asked for a Kiva loan two times already, she now is requesting her third loan in the amount of $200 to purchase weaving materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: purchasing weaving materials

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a single woman with five children, one of whom currently attends school (four have graduated). She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For over ten years, she has operated her food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Rehema faces the major challenge of seasonality and generally has fewer customers during the rainy season. She hopes to own a hotel in the future.  

She decided to join Yehu because of its simple loan procedures and minimum collateral requirements. With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase utensils and stocks of food.

loans.use: To purchase utensils and stocks of food

loans.name: Esther Adjoa Amoatemah

texts.en: Esther Adjoa Amoatemah A. is divorced and has six dependents. She has been through senior high school.  She sells doughnuts and fried fish at Abura,which she has been doing for ten years now. Esther is asking to add the loan to her initial capital to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to reinvest.

loans.use: add the loan to her initial capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita L. is from San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur.  She is 42 years old. She wants to provide her family with all the things they need. She wants her children to finish school as a result of improving her family's economic living standards. 

She would like to apply for a loan at CEVI. “By having an access to funds, I could buy farm supplies and seeds. In that way, I will be able to earn a better income.”

Teresita chose CEVI as her MFI because it has a micro-insurance coverage program for all of its clients.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, gallons of oil, beans, tomatoes, seasoning, bitter balls, etc.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es: Jessica, de 40 años, vive en su casa que es propia al lado de su esposo Carlos (41) y sus 2 menores hijos; cada día  juntos se esfuerzan para progresar. Esta trabajadora dama se dedica, desde hace 15 años, a la fabricación de zapatillas y zapatos en el taller que instaló en su vivienda. Le gusta mucho su labor pues la desempeña en compañía de su esposo, durante todo el día de lunes a sábado, dice que aprendió desde muy joven pues veía como algunos familiares fabricaban todo tipo de calzados. Manifiesta que es una labor bastante rentable, porque en su taller trabajan en base a pedidos que les realizan grandes comerciantes de zapatos de los principales emporios comerciales de la ciudad. Como es muy emprendedora para el futuro tiene planeado continuar dedicándose al mismo rubro de fabricación de calzado, pero tiene el anhelo de ampliar el negocio, de esta manera espera seguir progresando. Es el 20 avo crédito que tiene con MFP y como es una cliente antigua promete pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, pues esta muy agradecida con las personas que hicieron posible este aporte que le permitirá continuar trabajando en busca del progreso. Jessica tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de material que necesita para continuar elaborando las zapatillas y calzado pues tiene un pedido grande que espera cumplir para mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en: Jessica, 40 years old, lives in her own home together with her husband Carlos, 41, and their 2 young children. They work every day to improve their lives. This hardworking woman has been a cobbler for the past 15 years, making casual and dress shoes in a shop installed in her home. She greatly enjoys working in the company of her husband, every day from Monday to Saturday.  She learned the trade since she was very young while watching family members making all kinds of shoes. This is a very profitable business because in they start projects after receiving orders from large shoe distributors, the largest retailers in the city. She is very enterprising so in the future she plans on keeping up with her cobbler business. This is her 20th loan through MFP (Kiva Field Partner) and as she is a very experienced member, she knows that she must repay the loan on time. She is very grateful to all of those individuals who made this possible. She will be able to continue to her work and to improve her business. Jessica's plan is to invest the loan she has requested in the purchase of materials that she needs to make casual and dress shoes. She has a large order that has been placed and she wants to fill it and improve her earnings.

loans.use: To purchase materials for shoe-making

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad is a 39 year old married woman who supports her family by operating a hardware store. She lives in San Remegio, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her hardware business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 9,000 PHP. 

Caridad is borrowing 13,000 PHP to fund the operation of her hardware business. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP, which she fully repaid, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Caridad aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through its alleviation program, NWTF is empowering women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to fund hardware store operation

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora Maria R. B. tiene 48 años de edad y esta casada con el señor Epifanio con el cual tiene un hijo de 22 años de edad de nombre Esteban el cual ya trabaja  y la ayuda con los gastos del hogar, doña Maria y su familia viven en la comunidad de Vista Hermosa que pertenece al municipio de Tierra Blanca en el estado de Veracruz. 
Doña Mary  como la conocen en su comunidad nos platica que hace mas de un años decidio iniciar con su propio negocio para ayudar a su esposo e hijo con los gastos del hogar, ella vende leña  la  cual va a buscar al campo con su hijo hacen rollos los cueales  venden en el pueblo, tambien cria cerdos  en un pequeño corral que tiene en la parte de atras de su casa ella nos platica que inicio con un cerdo y con las ganancias que le dejo la venta de su cerdo compro dos mas, ella necesita este credito para invertirlo en la compra de cerdos y alimentos. Doña Mary nos dice que espera en un futuro hacer un corral de material(block, barilla y semento) y comprar mas cerdos para seguir trabajando en la cria de animales.
la casa de doña Mary es de madera y palma y desea en un futuro hacerla de material para mejorar su vivienda y no pasar mas frio en las temporadas desembrinas. Ella tambien nos expreso su agradecimiento por la confianza que le brindo la fundacion al otorgarle este prestamo.
texts.en:
Maria R. B. is 48 years old.  She is married to Epifanio and they have one son, Esteban, who is 22 years old.  Their son works and helps his mom with their household expenses.  Maria and her family live in Vista Hermosa community, in the town of Tierra Blanca, in the State of Veracruz.  Mary (as she is known in her community) tells us that over a year ago she decided to set up her own business in order to help her husband and son with their household expenses.  She sells firewood which she goes out to the countryside to find together with her son.  They make bundles and sell them in the town.  Maria also raises pigs in a small pen located behind her home.  She tells us that she started out with one pig and, with the profits she made from selling it, she bought two more.  Maria needs this loan to invest in buying pigs and feed.

Mary tells us that she hopes, in the future, to build a pen from blocks, iron rods and cement, and to buy more pigs so that she can continue raising animals.  Mary's house is made from wood and palm leaves.  In the future, she would like to re-build it from more solid material in order to improve her home so that she doesn't get cold any more during the winter months.  Mary is grateful for the trust that our foundation has placed in her by granting her this loan.

loans.use: To buy firewood and pigs

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa N. operates a food joint at Abbrem Agona near Abura Cape Coast. She cooks varieties of food such as fufu (a thick paste made by pounding boiled cassava and plantain, as shown in the picture), banku (another staple made from a mix of fermented corn and cassava dough), boiled yam and others. Adjoa is a widow and has six dependants. She is responsible for the general upkeep of her home.
